message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has symptoms of Cushing’s syndrome and a pituitary adenoma detected by MRI. Transsphenoidal pituitary adenoidectomy is the optimal therapy for Cushing’s syndrome caused by pituitary adenomas. Medical therapy would not remove the source of excess cortisol production. Adrenalectomy is indicated for adrenal adenomas or hyperplasia, but not for pituitary adenomas.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has symptoms of Cushing's syndrome, and the MRI confirmed a pituitary adenoma. The optimal therapy for this patient is transsphenoidal pituitary adenoidectomy to remove the adenoma and treat the underlying cause. Medical therapy may be used to control symptoms before surgery, but surgery is the definitive treatment. Adrenalectomy is not appropriate as the cause of the syndrome is from the pituitary adenoma, and bilateral adrenalectomy is only considered as a last resort if there is no other treatment option available.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has symptoms of Cushing's syndrome caused by a pituitary adenoma, so the optimal therapy would be transsphenoidal pituitary adenoidectomy. Medical therapy may be used as a temporary measure to control symptoms prior to surgery, but it's not a definitive treatment. Unilateral or bilateral adrenalectomy is not appropriate in this case because the source of the problem is the pituitary gland, not the adrenal glands.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has signs of Cushing's syndrome, such as weight gain and elevated cortisol levels. The imaging shows a pituitary adenoma, which suggests Cushing's disease. Therefore, the optimal therapy is transsphenoidal pituitary adenoidectomy to remove the cause of excess cortisol production. Medical therapy, adrenalectomies, or other surgeries would not address the underlying problem.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has Cushing's syndrome, which is caused by hypercortisolism. The elevated cortisol and ACTH, along with the pituitary adenoma, suggest Cushing's disease. The optimal therapy for Cushing's disease is transsphenoidal pituitary adenoidectomy. Medical therapy and adrenalectomy are used to treat other forms of Cushing's syndrome, and bilateral adrenalectomy is a last resort.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The elevated salivary cortisol level, high ACTH level, and pituitary adenoma suggest Cushing’s disease. The optimal therapy for Cushing’s disease is transsphenoidal pituitary adenoidectomy. Medical therapy can be used as a temporary measure and bilateral adrenalectomy is only used in severe cases. Unilateral adrenalectomy is not the optimal therapy for Cushing’s disease.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms suggest Cushing's syndrome caused by a pituitary adenoma. Transsphenoidal pituitary adenoidectomy is the optimal therapy to remove the source of excess ACTH secretion. Medical therapy can be used to control symptoms before surgery, but it should not replace surgery. Unilateral or bilateral adrenalectomy is used to treat Cushing's syndrome caused by adrenal tumors, but in this case, the pituitary adenoma is the source of excess ACTH secretion.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms, elevated cortisol and ACTH, and the pituitary adenoma on MRI suggest a diagnosis of Cushing’s disease. The optimal therapy for Cushing’s disease is transsphenoidal pituitary adenomectomy to remove the pituitary adenoma. Medical therapy and adrenalectomy are not effective for treating Cushing’s disease. Bilateral adrenalectomy is only considered for severe cases or as a last resort.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest Cushing’s syndrome, and the MRI shows a pituitary adenoma. The optimal therapy for this patient is transsphenoidal pituitary adenoidectomy to remove the adenoma and normalize hormone levels. Medical therapy can be tried but is not generally effective in curing the condition. Unilateral or bilateral adrenalectomy may be considered in cases where there is adrenal hyperplasia or adenomas, but in this case, the source of the excess cortisol production is the pituitary gland.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has features of Cushing’s syndrome, which can be caused by pituitary adenoma secreting adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH). The optimal therapy for this patient is transsphenoidal pituitary adenoidectomy to remove the pituitary adenoma causing the excess ACTH secretion. Medical therapy can be used to control symptoms before surgery or if surgery is not possible. Adrenalectomy is not indicated in this case as the cause of excess cortisol production is not due to adrenal tumor or hyperplasia.
